name: Acacia Flat
description: Explore the "cradle of conservation", the Blue Gum Forest. Enjoy birdwatching, long walks and plenty of photogenic flora.

name: Alexanders Hut
description:
An historic timber slab hut that was occupied until the 1980s. Today it provides shelter and very basic facilities for bushwalkers and visitors. Camping on the grounds of the hut is also permitted.

Nunnock Swamp walking trail is nearby and there are opportunities for bird-watching and seeing wildflowers. It's an important site for early European cultural heritage.

name: Apsley Falls campground
description: This informal bushland setting, separated from the picnic area, gives easy access to Apsley Gorge Rim Walk and Oxley Walk.

name: Bald Rock camping area
description: From here, you can walk to Bald Rock summit, Little Bald Rock, or north to a viewing area beside the Queensland border.

name: Balor Hut campground
description:
Balor Hut is the last remaining walkers hut in the Warrumbungle National Park. The campground is a 'walk-in' area at the base of The Breadknife and Grand High Tops. It's a great starting point for early morning walks to Bluff Mountain or even as far as Mount Exmouth.

There are eight (8) slab bunks in the hut but you will need to bring all your own bedding. There is a solid fuel fire in the hut and fireplace outside but you MUST bring your own firewood and adhere to fire season warnings.

name: Banksia Green campground
description: This campground is directly behind the park's dunes, with short walking access to the beach. There is good beach fishing, but surf conditions are often rough. The campground is close to Mungo Brush Rainforest Loop and the Tamboi walk.

name: Bark Hut campground
description: The Scutts Hut and Euglah Rock Lookout walking tracks start from near this campground. If you're planning to use the wood barbecues, you'll need to bring your own firewood.

name: Barokee campground
description: From this campground, you can take an exhilarating walk to Cathedral Rock or relax and enjoy the wildlife around the campsite.

name: Behrs Flat campground
description: There are no set campsites at this campground.

name: Ben Halls camping ground
description: This campground has large, level, grassed campsites just beside the historic Seaton's Farm. Ben Halls Cave, the famous bushranger's hide-out, is a half-hour walk away. You'll need to bring drinking water, and there are no powered sites.

name: Bendethera Valley campground
description: This campground is in an open valley, with river crossings and grassy flats. It's good for walking, swimming, caving and picnicking.

name: Berlang Camping Area
description: This campsite is a good spot for caving, walks to the Big Hole and Marble Arch, and swimming. There are 10 to 15 unmarked tent sites.

name: Big River Camp
description: You'll need to bring drinking water and firewood. Please take rubbish with you.

name: Black Rocks campground
description: This campground gives easy access to Ten Mile Beach. You'll need to bring your own water and firewood.

name: Blatherarm camping and picnic area
description: Next to Blather Creek, this campground is popular for fossicking topaz and for nature walks.

name: Blue Gums large group campground
description: This is a unique camping area, catering for large groups (up to 100 people) or small vehicle-based bush camping. This area is suitable for 4WD touring, cycling, horseriding and wilderness walks - or just simply relaxing in a remote location.

name: Blue Waterholes campground
description: From this campground you can access the Jennings walks track heads (Clarke Gorge and Nichols Gorge walking tracks). There are only three adventure caves open to the public. Nichols Gorge walk includes Cooleman and Murray caves and Clarke Gorge walk provides access to Barbers Cave and Cave Creek waterfall. The nearby lookout has excellent views to Cave Creek and spectacular limestone cliffs.

name: Bonnie Vale camping ground
description:
The main feature of Bonnie Vale is its large sand spit, where there's good swimming. Wood fired and solid fuel barbecues are prohibited. There are no powered sites.

Please note that some campsites are temporarily unavailable and will be allocated according to availability.

name: Boolambayte Lake
description:
The following camping areas are located around the Two-mile and Boolambayte Lakes:

Korsmans Landing (26 sites) Bungaree Bay (7 sites) Violet Hill (40 sites).

name: Boomeri campground
description: This camping area is set away from the lake shore amongst stunning smooth-barked Angopheras and grass trees. You can walk or cycle along the Old Gibber Track to Johnson's Beach from here. Wood and solid fuel fires are not permitted.

name: Boorkoom campground
description: You'll find swimming and fishing spots close by. Wilsons Headland Walk (3km one way, grade easy) links Boorkoom Camping Area to the Wilsons Headland Picnic Area. Bring your own water.

name: Boundary Falls
description: Boundary Falls picnic and camping area is in a dry forest, on the site of an old sawmill. There are spectacular waterfalls nearby. This is a good starting point for a day walk to Duffer Creek or continuing to do the 60 kilometre circuit called the World Heritage Walk. Signs tell of the local history and wildlife. The Gibraltar Range Waratahs and other shrubs flower here, especially from mid-October to December. Facilities include modern fire and cooking stands, pit toilets and picnic tables. Bring your own drinking water and firewood. No pets are allowed in the park.

name: Boyd River campground
description: This camping ground is set among snow gums. At night you can see greater gliders, sugar gliders, brushtail possums, tawny frogmouths, wombats, wallabies and kangaroos. Please bring firewood with you.

name: Bradley's/O'Brien's Hut
description: There are no set campsites at this campground.

name: Bradneys Gap campground
description: There are no set campsites at this campground.

name: Brambles Green campground
description: This boat-based camping area is an ideal overnight stop for kayakers and canoeists paddling the lower Myall River and for hikers on the Brambles Green-Tamboi walk. It is a small grassy area directly beside the river.

name: Brou Lake
description: Campers at Brou Lake can enjoy beach and lake fishing, surfing and beach walking. Batemans Marine Park is adjacent to Brou Lake camping area, and there is a sanctuary zone where fishing is prohibited from immediately north of the entrance to Brou Lake to Jemisons Point. Parts of Brou Lake are also located within this sanctuary zone. Signs show those areas where fishing is not permitted. Fires are allowed but firewood is not supplied. Campers must bring their own drinking/washing water with them and remove all garbage from the site. The camping area is suitable for small caravans and campervans capable of travelling on unsealed roads.

name: Brushy Mountain campground
description: This campground offers a tranquil setting amid tall gum trees with active bird life. It's an ideal base for exploring the park's walking tracks or starting a longer trek into the wilderness. Spokes Lookout provides views across Willi Willi National Park to the coast. There is a large shelter shed.

name: Buddong Falls campground
description: The campground is at the track head to Buddong (Upper and Lower) Falls walk and is a small section of the Hume and Hovell walking track. There are basic facilities and no designated sites.

name: Budds Mare campground
description: This campground stands on the edge of the tablelands and has a spectacular lookout over the Apsley River Gorge. From the lookout, a walking track leads down the ridge to Riverside Visitor Area on the Apsley River.

name: Bullocks Hill campground
description: Vehicle based camping with horses is permitted at this campground. A horse yard is provided on site.

name: Bummaroo Ford camping ground
description: You can go swimming, fishing and canoeing at this campground (depending on water level). You'll need to bring drinking water.

name: Bungaree Bay campground
description: This small, secluded camping area is set close to the lake shore and is surrounded by paperbark and casuarina forest. Just minutes down the road, Violet Hill has a boat ramp.

name: Burbie Camp
description: This walk-in campground is located along the firetrail to Mount Exmouth. It's very basic with a spring water tap.

name: Burralow Creek camping ground
description:
Burralow is a beautiful picnic and camping area - so close to Sydney yet so far away. Set in a grassed open area among the scribbly gums this campground is ideally suited to families or small groups. Look out for the rare giant dragonfly on the Bulcamatta Falls convict walking track (one hour return; easy grade).

You'll need to bring drinking water and firewood with you - gathering native vegetation is strictly prohibited as it is valuable habitat for wildlife. You can buy firewood from local service stations at Richmond, North Richmond or Kurmond. Please take all garbage when you leave.

name: Camp Pincham
description: This is a walk-in camp from the Pincham carpark and a great place to camp. It was one of the first campgrounds in the Warrumbungles and is a starting point for walks to The Breadknife and Grand High Tops.

name: Camp Walaay
description: It's a short drive from this campground to the main walking tracks, and there are short walks and cycling routes nearby. The nearby Canyon Picnic Area has electric BBQs. The camping sites here are large and can accommodate from 30 to 200 people. Motor vehicles must not leave the sealed road and the area is not suitable for caravans or camper trailers. The Camp Blackman amenities block is close by.

name: Camp Wambelong
description: The campground is close to walking tracks that lead to Split Rock, the Grand High Tops and Mount Exmouth.

name: Cascades camping ground
description: A walking track leads from this campground to a viewing platform overlooking Tuross Falls. There is a new viewing platform 100 m from the carpark overlooking the Cascades and gorge downstream. You'll need to bring drinking water.

name: Chaelundi campground
description: This campground is set amid a forest of gums and stringybarks, beside the delightful Chaelundi Creek. The creek is home to rare New England tree frogs - please don't pollute the water with soap, toothpaste or detergent. From the campground, you can swim and take easy walks with spectacular views.

name: Clover Flat campground
description: There are no set campsites at this campground.

name: Colo Meroo camping ground
description: You'll need to bring drinking water and firewood with you. Please take all garbage when you leave. Check river levels before your visit - the river can flood.

name: Congo camping area
description: This campground is great for beach fishing, surfing and beach walking. Campfires are not permitted at the Congo camping area.

name: Cooinbil Hut campground
description: There is a walk-in and vehicle-based camping area on the northern side of the hut and a vehicle-based camping area with horses to the south. You'll find a loading ramp and horse yards. Historic Cooinbil Hut is adjacent to the camping areas.

name: Cooleman Mountain campground
description: The campground is on the access road to Blue Waterholes and protected by the Cooleman Mountain gums. The Cooleman Plain karst area is adjacent to the mountain.

name: Coorongooba camping ground
description: You'll need to bring drinking water and firewood with you to this secluded campground. There are no toilets at this location. Please take all garbage when you leave.

name: Coxs Creek camping ground
description: An alternative to The Barracks, this campground is just beside Coxs Creek Falls. You'll need to bring drinking water and firewood.

name: Culgoa
description: Camp among the gidgee trees a short walk from the river. Riverbank Walk and Connellys Walk start here.

name: Cutters camp
description: The campground features a walking track to Byrrill Creek. Due to the unsealed road and the layout of the campsite it is only suitable for small camper trailers or small campervans, not for full sized caravans or motor homes.

name: Cypress-pine camping area
description: There are interesting walks along the Boonoo Boonoo River. You'll see excellent wildflower displays in spring, and birds, wallabies and even platypus may be seen along the river.

name: Dalmorton Camping Area
parkName: Guy Fawkes River State Conservation Area
description: This camping area offers camping along the Boyd River and an opportunity to explore the ghost town of Dalmorton with on-site information provided.

name: Dead Horse Gully campground
description: This large campground is set among the granite boulders surrounding Tibooburra. A signposted walking track starts at the the campsite and passes through granite outcrops, giving you a chance to see euros, red kangaroos and reptiles. After rain, you may also see Sturt's desert peas. Wood fires are not allowed here.

name: Dees Corner campground
description: The camping area is close to both the lake and the beach. It connects directly with Mungo Brush via the Rainforest walking track. The Mungo 4 wheel drive beach access track is also nearby.

name: Denison campground
description: The campground provides access to Eucumbene River/Dam.

name: Deua River campground
description: These campgrounds are great spots for canoeing, fishing and swimming. Bakers Flat campground is not suitable for camper trailers - sites are a short walk (70m) from the road.

name: Devils Hole campground
description: This basic campground, at 1400m altitude, offers spectacular views over the Barrington wilderness and nearby farmlands. Toilets, picnic facilities and fireplaces are across the road at Devils Hole Lookout. You can go fishing nearby.

name: Dingo Dell campground
description: The campsite is situated beside Tuglow Hole Creek. This creek is quite small but has some waterholes big enough to cool down in if the weather is hot.If you're planning on cooking, please bring your own fuel stove or firewood. Visitors should camp in designated sites to avoid trespassing on private property.

name: Dingo Tops camping ground
description: This campground is near Dingo Tops forest park, which features relic forestry machinery and walking tracks into the park's variety of forests. You'll need to bring drinking water.

name: Dry Tank camping ground
description: From this camping ground, you can go on a 2.4km walk through mulga woodlands to nearby Little Mountain. From the top of the mountain, there's an outstanding view of the entire northern escarpment of the Gunderbooka Range.

name: Dunns Swamp camping ground
description: You'll need to bring drinking water with you to this popular campground, and limited firewood is supplied on-site. A self-registration system applies here - please bring correct change. Please take all garbage when you leave.

name: Emu Lake camping ground
description: Hot showers and bore water are available at the Shearer's Quarters at the historic woolshed.

name: Euroka campground
description:
This grassy area near the beautiful Nepean River gorge is well known for its population of eastern grey kangaroos. There are five camping areas: Appletree Flat, Redgum, Nioka, Bennets Ridge and Daruk. Each area is suitable for 20 people.

There are picnic tables and fireplaces; bring your own gas/fuel stove or firewood. It is forbidden to collect firewood from the bush at Euroka.

Flush toilets are available at the rangers station while pit toilets are provided at Euroka campground.

name: Euroka campground - Appletree Flat campervan and camper trailer area
description:
See the general Euroka campground information for facilities and activities. NOTE: Bring your own firewood - collecting firewood from the bush at Euroka is prohibited. 

Please note that the campervan sites are suitable for small campervans or campertrailers - the sites are adjacent to the road edge.

name: Federal Falls camping area
description: From this camping ground, you can head off along various walking tracks, including the popular Federal Falls track. Along these walks, you can see how subalpine vegetation gives way to moist forest as the altitude changes. You'll also see heathland among the rocky outcrops. Many different bird species gather in this area.

name: Finchley campground
description: This campsite is on the Yango Track, and offers excellent 4WD day touring drives. It's a short walk from the campground to Finchley Aboriginal Area. You'll need to bring your own firewood and drinking water.

name: Forest Tops campground
description: The Booyong walking track starts here.

name: Frazer camping ground
description: This small camping ground is set in a quiet, protected pocket of the Frazer Valley a short walk away from Frazer Beach. It has quick, easy access to Snapper Point, a popular fishing spot. Each of the six sites has room for up to six people. You can stay for a maximum of two weeks.

name: Freshwater campground
description: This boat-based camping area is located on Two Mile Lake and features sandy beaches and shallow waters adjacent to the camping area.

name: Gambells Rest campground
description: This area offers great bushwalking, with 11 identified walking tracks, plus cycling. Maximum of five people per site. Children under 5 free.

name: Gentlemans Halt camping ground
description: You'll need to bring your own drinking water if you're camping here.

name: Ghost Gully campground
description: Vehicle based camping with horses is permitted at this campground. Loading ramp and horse yards are provided on site.

name: Gillards campground
description:
At this campground, you can enjoy fishing from the beach, surfing and beach walking. 

Extra information about camping at this campground: you'll need to bring your own drinking water. Maximum length of stay: two weeks during school holiday periods; four weeks at other times.

name: Green Gully campground
description: You'll find walking tracks and lookouts overlooking the spectacular Chandler and Wollomombi Rivers here.

name: Greenbah camping ground
description: This campground is beside Greenbah Creek. It's an excellent spot for birdwatching. You can walk to Burrabadine Peak, or go cycling along the access trail to the campground.

name: Group campground
description: Here you can enjoy Willandra Creek and a walking track. The homestead precinct is nearby.

name: Gummi Falls campground
description: Small secluded camping area with basic facilities.

name: Gunneemooroo campground
description: Gunneemooroo is located in the southern side of the Warrumbungle National Park.

name: Halls Peak campground
description: The Halls Peak camping area caters for self-reliant visitors looking to experience the seclusion of remote camping in an idyllic and peaceful setting.

name: Horse Swamp campground
description: Small secluded camping area with basic facilities. Polblue Falls picnic area and Polblue Falls walk are 150m to the north.

name: Humes Crossing campground
description: There are no designated sites at this campground.

name: Hungry Gate camping area
description: This campground is in a delightful setting, protected by the park's unspoiled sand dunes. The area is surrounded by thick heath and woodland vegetation. You'll need to bring drinking water. There is a recycling station, however, taking all your garbage away is appreciated.

name: Illaroo campground
description: There's easy access to the beach and a walk-in camp area at Rocky Point with no facilities. Two easy short walks start at Illaroo: the Rocky Point Track (2km return) and the Angophora Grove Walk (1km return) towards Minnie Water village.

name: Ingar campground
description: This camping ground is set among scribbly gums. The dam on Ingar Creek is suitable for paddling and swimming, and you can also walk or ride your mountain bike to Bedford Creek, via Murphy's Fire Trail. The campground is not suitable for caravans or large campervans.

name: Island Bend campground
description: There are no set campsites at this campground.

name: Jacob's River campground
description: This is a pleasant spot for a picnic and for camping. There are no set campsites at this campground.

name: Joes Cove campground
description: This small, secluded camping area is located at the base of Two Mile Lake.

name: Johnsons Beach campground
description: This is one of the larger boat-based camping areas. It features sandy beaches and shallow waters adjacent to the camping area. There are a number of walking tracks nearby, including Johnsons Hill track and the Old Gibber track.

name: Jounama Creek campground 1
description: Camping is permitted on the mowed area between the access road and Jounama Creek.

name: Junction Pools campground
description: You'll find swimming spots at this campground. It's close to walking tracks on the Barrington Tops Plateau, drive touring, lookouts, fishing and 4WD trails.

name: Kingfisher Pool camping ground
description: This camping ground fits up to 18 campers. You'll need to bring your own drinking water.

name: Koreelah Creek camping area
description:
This is a pleasant camping spot at the small grassy area beside Koreelah Creek.

Firewood collection within the park is not permitted. Please bring your own firewood.

name: Korsmans Landing campground
description: This campground is set within open eucalypt forest and you might see eastern grey kangaroos grazing nearby. There is a wharf and an unsealed boat ramp.

name: Kosciuszko camping grounds
description: There are many camping grounds throughout the park, though most have only basic facilities such as pit toilets and fireplaces.

name: Lake Arragan and Red Cliff campgrounds
description: Explore isolated beaches or canoe on Lake Arragan. A 10km walking track takes you north to Angourie.

name: Lake Cawndilla camping ground
description: From this campground you can enjoy a walk along the shores of the lake - especially recommended in the early morning and towards sunset. The campground is ideal for large groups. You'll need to bring drinking water and firewood with you. Hot showers and bore water are available at the Shearer's Quarters at the historic woolshed.

name: Lake Creek camping ground
description: This campground is in a bushland setting, next to Lake Creek. You'll need to bring drinking water.

name: Lane Cove River tourist park
description: This beautiful spot offers bushland camping and caravanning only 10 km from the heart of Sydney. Public transport is available from the tourist park to Sydney CBD. Powered and unpowered sites are available for caravans, campervans, motorhomes and tents. You can choose caravan sites with or without concrete slabs and sullage. The tourist park has a swimming pool, camp kitchen, laundry, TV room and internet access. Enjoy a bushwalk or picnic in the Lane Cove National Park.

name: Leatherbarrel Creek campground
description: There are no set campsites at this campground.

name: Little Beach camping area
description: Bouddi Coastal Walk, picnicking, and fishing. Wood fires are not permitted.

name: Log Bridge Creek campground
description: There are no designated campsites at this campground.

name: Long Plain Hut campground
description: Vehicle based camping with horses is permitted in the designated area east of Long Plain Hut (horse yards on site). Walk-in and other vehicle-based camping are provided north of the hut.

name: Long Point campground
description: Located in a small forest clearing, this campground gives easy access to Cassinia Walk, Chandler View Circuit Walk and the Long Point to Wollomombi overnight bushwalk.

name: Mackaway Bay campground
description: This small, secluded camping area is located on the narrow stretch of water between Two Mile and Boolambayte lakes. It is often sheltered during windy conditions.

name: Mann River picnic and camping area
Marramarra Creek camping ground
description: You'll need to bring your own drinking water if you're camping here.

name: Melaleuca camping ground
description: You'll need to bring drinking water and firewood with you. You can explore rare rainforests on a short loop track from this campground.

name: Middle Beach campground
description:
From here you can enjoy fishing, surfing, beach walking and canoeing. 

Extra information about camping at this campground: campsites are around 100m from car parking. You'll need to bring your own drinking water. Maximum length of stay: two weeks during school holiday periods; four weeks at other times.

name: Mogo Creek campground
description: You'll be camping at the top of the Old Great North Road here. There are excellent bushwalks around this historic convict-built road. The campground is also a great base for day tour drives into Macdonald Valley (historic buildings), Wollombi Valley (vineyards) and Koolang Observatory.

name: Mooraback campground
description: This basic camping area is on the western edge of a clearing and kangaroos commonly visit the area. You can follow the Mooraback Trail, a short loop walk from the campground. The Platypus Pools walk also starts from the camping area and its 6km loop takes you along the upper reaches of the Hastings River where platypus are often seen.

name: Mount Werong campground
description: This camping area surrounds a stone hut which you can use for cooking and temporary shelter. You'll find covered picnic tables and fireplaces here - but bring your own firewood.

name: Mount Wood campground
description: This campground is set in view of the historic Mount Wood Homestead Complex in the rolling gibber downs on the eastern side of the park. Here you may see red kangaroos, euros and eastern grey kangaroos, plus lots of birds and reptiles. There is small signposted walk around the historic complex.

name: Murphys Glen campground
description: This is a secluded camping ground in a forest of tall eucalypt, turpentine and angophora trees. A short, steep walk through the rainforest will lead you to Bedford Creek. Fuel stoves can only be used here - no wood fires.

name: Myall Creek camping ground
description: This basic camping area is situated in a tall eucalypt forest beside Myall Creek, which flows throughout the year. From here, self-reliant bushwalkers can explore nearby waterfalls and rainforest. Contact the Ranger at the Walcha Office for advice on visiting scenic canyons, waterfalls and heritage places that are further from the campground.

name: Native Dog campground
description: From this campground you can walk to Woolpack Rocks and beyond to Cathedral Rock.

name: Neranie Head campground
description: This campground has good access to Myall Lake, and is perfect for lakeside activities. There's a boat ramp at nearby Hearts Point Picnic Area. You can also go on a short walk to the historic cemetery at Neranie Headland. Wood and solid fuel fires are not permitted.

name: New Country Swamp campground
description: This is a basic camping ground suitable for small groups. A short walk to the edge of Mummel Gulf offers breathtaking views. The campground is also a good spot for birdwatching and photography.

name: Newnes camping ground
description: You'll need to bring drinking water and firewood with you to this popular campground. Please take all garbage when you leave.

name: Ngarigo campground
description: There are no set campsites at this campground.

name: North Era campground
description: A maximum of 36 people can camp here. You'll need to bring your own drinking water, and wood fires are forbidden.

name: Nunnock campground
description: This is a small camping area beside Cattleman's Link Trail. Grasslands, frost hollows and a high altitude perched swamp are features nearby. Stroll along an easy 4km loop track from the campground. Stop at lookouts over the swamp along the way.

name: O'Hares rest area
description: The campground was a former Snowy Mountains Hydro Electric Scheme site and provides boating access to the southern end of Talbingo Reservoir. There are no designated campsites.

name: Old Geehi campground
description: There are no set campsites at this campground.

name: Old Snowy campground
description: Vehicle based camping with horses is permitted at this campground. Horse yards are provided on site.

name: Olive Downs campground
description: This campground is set amongst mulga trees on top of the 'Jump-Up' Range. A walking track starts at the campground and leads you through the Jump-Up landscape. You may see various species of kangaroos, lots of birds and reptiles, and some relics from the park's pastoral history. Wood fires are prohibited.

name: Peacock Creek camping area
description: Firewood collection within the park is not permitted. Please bring your own firewood.

name: Pebbly Beach campground
description:
Here you'll find places to swim and fish. You'll need to bring your own water. Freshwater Track is 4km return, grade medium. Corkwood and Scribbly Gum Walking Track follows the creek upstream. It's 1.5km return, easy grade.

This camping area is not suitable for large caravans but is suitable for small caravans and trailers if towed by high clearance 4WD.

Firewood is provided for open fire places.

name: Pebbly Beach campground and picnic area
Perrys Lookdown campground
description: You'll be pitching your tent on prime real estate here, beside one of the mountains' best lookouts. The camping ground offers spectacular views of the Grose Valley and Mount Banks - together with basic toilet facilities. It's a great base for walking trips in the valley below. You'll need to bring drinking water and a fuel stove: camp fires are forbidden. You can only stay for one night.

name: Plateau Beech campground
description: A walking track goes from this campground through Antarctic beech forests and past mountain streams and waterfalls.

name: Platypus Flat camping ground
description: You can picnic and swim at this campground. It's also a good spot to launch your canoe from. You'll need to bring drinking water.

name: Polblue campground
description: This is a roomy campground in pleasant subalpine woodland, at 1450m altitude. It offers short and inspiring walks passing through snow gum woodland, tall eucalypt forest and areas of high-altitude swamp.

name: Postman's camping area
description: Camp or picnic near a wide sandy bend of the Tantawangalo Creek. Campsites with fireplaces are provided. The campsite is on the track that was used by the postman delivering mail between the tablelands to Kameruka during the 1800s.

name: Pretty Beach campground
description:
There is an office at this campground, and a manager is present 7 days a week. Powered sites are available. Limited wood barbecues are available for cooking outside of peak season but it is recommended you bring fuel stoves to use while on the park grounds. NO FIRES are to be lit in the peak seasons (Christmas/Easter or long weekends).

Explore Durras mountain, enjoy the coastal walks or discover sea life on the rock platforms. Fishing, snorkelling, surfing and swimming are also popular pasttimes for campers and day visitors alike.

Eastern grey kangaroos, swamp wallabies, brushtail possums and a large variety of bird life can be seen in the campground or on the beach at various times throughout the day and night. When sighting birds and animals please remember they have their own foods and can become sick and/or aggressive once introduced to human foods.

name: Putty Beach camping area
description: The main features are at the eastern end of Putty Beach, which provides good swimming and the start of the Coastal Walk. Wood fires are not permitted. Important note: Showers are open-air.

name: Rivermouth campground
description: This boat-based camping area is an ideal overnight stop for kayakers and canoeists paddling the Upper Myall River. Camp sites are nestled into the bush a short distance from the riverbank.

name: Riverside campground
description: This campground lies deep within the Macleay Gorges, immediately adjacent to the Macleay Gorges Wilderness Area.

name: Rock Flat campground
description: There are no designated sites at this campground.

name: Rocky Plain campground
description: Vehicle based camping with horses is permitted at this campground. There is a loading ramp adjacent to the toilet facilities.

name: Samual Bollard campground
description: The campground was established primarily for campers treking the Hume and Hovell walking track, however it is open to most visitors.

name: Sandon River campground
description: This camping ground is close to Sandon River, a popular fishing spot with a boat ramp.

name: Scotchie's Yards campground
description: There are no set campsites at this campground.

name: Shelley Head campground
description: Campsites are close to Shelley Caves, Little Shelley Beach and Caves Beach, where you can swim and fish. Bring your own water and fuel stove.

name: Shelly Beach campground
description: This is one of the larger boat-based camping areas. It features sandy beaches with shallow water along the lake shore. There are opportunities for walking nearby along the Old Gibber track.

name: Silent Creek camping ground
description: This campground is good for large groups. You'll need to bring drinking water and firewood. Silent Creek is often dry.

name: Six Mile Creek campground
description:
Picnic, walk, camp or just sit and relax by the pristine waters of Six Mile Creek. The original Tantawangalo Mountain Road to this site was forged around 1860. 

Across the road from the picnic area is the start of an easy 20 minute walk (300m return). A viewing platform overlooks the cascading waters on their way to meet Tantawangalo Creek.

This is a great place for walking and scenic drives.

name: Smoky Cape camping area
description: This low-key campground is nestled among the rainforest just below the lighthouse at Smoky Cape, on a beautiful, isolated stretch of the coast. You'll need to bring drinking water. There is a recycling station, however, taking all your garbage away is appreciated.

name: Spring Gully Camp
description: You'll need to bring drinking water and firewood. Please take rubbish with you.

name: Station Creek campground
description: Swimming and fishing is available very close to this camping area. Canoeists can enjoy Station Creek. Corkwood and Scribbly Gum Walking Track follows the creek upstream. Bring your own water.

name: Stewart and Lloyds campground
description: This campground is directly behind the park's extensive sand dunes, and has walking tracks across the dunes to the beach. There is good beach fishing, but surf conditions are often rough.

name: Sunnyside camping area
description: This boat-based camping area is located on the narrow stretch of water between Two Mile and Boolambayte Lakes. It is at the site of the former Sunnyside Guesthouse.

name: Tallow Beach camping ground
description: Tallow Beach is an unpatrolled beach where you can swim, surf and fish. Box Head walking track and Flannel Flower/Lobster Beach walking tracks are nearby. No barbecues are provided and wood fires are not permitted (fuel stoves only).

name: Ten Mile Hollow campground
description: This camping ground is a great place to stop and rest if you're doing the two-day Old Great North Road walk, from Wisemans Ferry to Mangrove Mountain or the three-day walk to Mount Manning. You'll only find fireplaces here, so bring plenty of water.

name: Terarra Creek
description: The campground's central location makes it a good spot for exploring the park. It's ideal for bird watchers, bushwalkers and mountain bikers. You can also drive to Mount Nangar Lookout from the campground (4WD only).

name: The Barracks camping ground
description: This campground is an ideal base-camp for walking trips. Caravan sites are very limited. You'll need to bring drinking water and firewood.

name: The Beach
description: This campground is in a secluded spot beside the Abercrombie River. You'll need to bring drinking water and firewood.

name: The Diggings campground
description: This camping ground is beside the Turon River, site of the goldrush from 1851. Panning or digging for gold are not allowed, but you can go bushwalking, fishing (with a fishing licence) and birdwatching.

name: The Junction campground
description: You can picnic and swim at this campground and it's a good spot to launch your canoe. You'll need to bring drinking water.

name: The Pines campground
description: There are no designated sites at this campground.

name: The Pines camping ground
description: This is a large and open campground near to Norfolk Island Swamp. You'll need to bring drinking water and firewood.

name: The Sink
description: This campground offers fishing, swimming (depending on water level) and bushwalking. You'll need to bring drinking water and firewood. This campground is beside the Retreat River.

name: The Wells campground
description: This camping area is located on the eastern shore of Bombah Broadwater. It is one of the areas around the Broadwater where campfires are permitted.

name: Thredbo Diggings campground
description: There are no set campsites at this campground.

name: Three Mile Dam East campground
description:
The eastern side of Three Mile Dam has several clear areas for camping. The most sheltered place is within the tree line, near the public facilities. There are no designated sites at this campground.

Three Mile Dam and the surrounding plains provide a spectacular wildflower display during early to mid-summer.

name: Three Mile Dam West campground
description:
This campground is located along the peninsular of Three Mile Dam, sheltered amongst the snow gums. There are basic public facilities and no designated campsites.

The surrounding plains provide a spectacular wildflower display during early to mid-summer. Take Gold Seekers Walk to enjoy the scenery of the snow gums, heath and wildflowers as well as relics of the mining era. Gold Seekers Walk starts adjacent to the carpark next to the Three Mile Dam peninsular access road.

name: Tia Falls campground
description: The campground is situated in quiet, picturesque woodland. Enjoy the Tia Falls and Tiara walking tracks.

name: Tin Mines campground
description: The campground is a clear grassy area adjacent to Tin Mines Trail. The site has basic camping facilities and is suitable for 4WD vehicle based camping or self reliant backpackers. It's located along the Hume and Hovell walking track which extends from Yass to Albury.

name: Tom Groggin campground
description: There are no set campsites at this campground.

name: Two Mile Sands campground
description: This boat-based camping area is located on Two Mile Lake and features sandy beaches and shallow waters adjacent to the camping area. A short walking track connects the camp sites.

name: Uloola Falls camping ground
description: A maximum of 18 people can camp here. You'll need to bring your own drinking water, and wood fires are forbidden.

name: Wallingat River camping ground
description: Walking tracks lead from this campground into the park.

name: Wanda Wandong camping ground
description: This campground is in an open woodland with a grassy understorey. There's lots of open space for kids.

name: Waratah Gully campground
description:
Camp amidst the towering eucalypts adjacent to the picturesque Waratah Gully. It's an ideal location from which to explore the Coolangubra section of the park, including Pheasants Peak and Myanba Gorge. 

The area is renowned for old growth forest and the diverse forest fauna it supports.

name: Wares Yards campground
description: Vehicle based camping with horses is permitted at this campground.

name: Warrabah camping ground
description: This campground is beside the Namoi River. You can go hiking, swimming, canoeing and fishing here. Camping is only permitted at numbered sites, as shown on the plan in the information shelter.

name: Washpools picnic and camping area
description: You'll need to bring your own fuel stove and water when you camp here.

name: Wheeny Creek camping ground
description: You'll need to bring drinking water and firewood with you. Please take all garbage when you leave.

name: White Tree Bay campground
description: This camping area is located on the eastern shore of Bombah Broadwater. It includes a large picnic area and gas barbecue.

name: Willandra campground
description: You'll find a walking track near this campground.

name: Wombat Creek campground
description: Wombat Creek is one of a number of bushwalking campsites in the park, but it's the only one with toilets. It's a great base for exploring the Barrington Tops plateau, and is only a few kilometres walk from Careys Peak.

name: Wombeyan Caves campground
description: There is an abundance of campsites along the picturesque Wombeyan Creek. There is a communal kithen and dining room with stove, barbecues, fridge, urn, tables and chairs. There are three amenities blocks with hot showers and flush toilets; wheelchair access provided. Fire places are provided, but you will need to bring your own firewood.

name: Woolshed Flat campground
description: This peaceful spot is where the Turon River begins. It's a great place for birdwatching and bushwalking.

name: Wyanbene Cave campground
description: The campground offers caving and bushwalking. There are 5 to 10 unmarked sites.

name: Yachting Point campground
description: This campground provides access to the Blowering Foreshores which is a popular place for water activities. There are no designated sites at this campground.

name: Yagon campground
description: This campground lies behind the dunes, with close walking access to the beach. Visit nearby Seal Rocks and the Sugarloaf Point Lighthouse. You can also go on overnight walks to Shelly Beach and Mungo Brush from here. Wood and solid fuel fires are not permitted.

name: Yarrangobilly Village campground
description:
This campground is close to Yarrangobilly Caves on the Yarrangobilly River. It's an ideal place to camp if visiting the caves, exploring the local area or fishing. There are no designated camping sites.

Yarrangobilly River meanders through the campground before cutting its way through the Yarrangobilly limestone belt heading to the caves, Lobs Hole Ravine and the Talbingo Reservoir.

name: Yolde campground
description: There are no designated sites at this campground.

name: Youdales campground
description: This campground is adjacent to two wilderness areas on the upper reaches of the picturesque Kunderang Brook. It's ideal for picnics, swimming and short walks. You can also visit the historic Youdales Hut.

name: Youngville camping area
description: This campground offers walking tracks, including the walk to Pieries Peak.

name: Sunny Side
description:
You'll find boat-based camping at the following locations:

Brambles Green (2 sites) Rivermouth (5 sites) Joes Cove (2 sites) Freshwater (7 sites) Two Mile Sands (4 sites) Mackaway Bay (3 sites) Johnsons Beach (17 sites) Shelly Beach (18 sites) Sunny Side (4 sites). There are toilets at Rivermouth, Freshwater, Johnsons Beach and Shelly Beach campgrounds only.

name: Bangalow campground
description: Camp amongst tall blue gums and blackbutts. This camping area is a short distance (1km) from Gap Creek camping area.
